member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Organism.BeginReproduction(System.Byte[])

summary.para: Use this function to command your creature to reproduce. There are many conditions on whether your creature can reproduce. If these conditions are not met, an exception will be thrown. The easiest way to make sure all pre-existing conditions have been met is to check the CanReproduce property.

If you call this method multiple times in the same turn, then the last call will be used, and all previous calls will be ignored. This method is also asynchronous, and a ReproduceCompletedEvent will be fired when your creature has actually given birth. The time between start and completion is 10 ticks.

member.param: A byte array that gets passed to the child. This can be any information you want to pass to the child creature. The byte array is truncated at 8000 bytes.
member.exception: Thrown when your creature is already in the process of reproduction.
Thrown when your creature is not yet mature and you try to reproduce.
Thrown when your creature does not have enough energy to start reproduction.
Thrown when your creature is not yet ready to reproduce because the appropriate number of ticks has not elapsed.

They are on the order of 12 nSec per call. To meet this performance requirement there are several overloads taking a varying number of parameters rather than a single variable argument parameter.

member.param: An object containing information for the Trace Window. ToString() will be called on the object.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Organism.TurnsSkipped

summary.para: A creature can get skipped for a number of turns if it takes too long to execute. There is a limit to the time an animal can use for processing every turn which is calculated dynamically by the Terrarium each time it starts based on your computer's processing power.

To see how long your creature takes to process, you can open the Trace window, unselect "Show Organism Traces", and then select your creature. Note that this time will be different depending on the machine.

If you do break the limit Terrarium determines how many ticks worth of time you've gone over the limit and sets this property. You can examine this property to recover from conditions where your creature is skipped for a given number of turns. This is useful since you may not receive events that fire while during the time your creature's turn is being skipped.

member.returns: A System.Int32 value for the number of turns the creature was skipped before it was assigned another time slice.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.SerializeAnimal(System.IO.MemoryStream)

summary.para: This method should be overridden by any class inheriting from Animal. This method is called with a MemoryStream that the user can place any data on they wish to Serialize during save games or while being teleported.

The complement of this method is the DeserializeAnimal method which is called to deserialize the data when the creature is restored. Authors should be careful when writing to a MemoryStream since it will be truncated at 8000bytes.

member.param: MemoryStream used by the creature to serialize data.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.DeserializeAnimal(System.IO.MemoryStream)

summary.para: This method should be overridden by any class inheriting from Animal. This method is called with a MemoryStream that the user can read any data from that was written during the call to SerializeAnimal.
Care should be taken when reading from a MemoryStream since the values may have been truncated at 8000bytes if more than 8000bytes were originally written.

member.param: MemoryStream used by the creature to deserialize data.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.Scan

summary.para: Scans the world around your creature's current location in a circular area and returns an ArrayList of OrganismState objects representing what was seen.

The radius scanned by your creature is dependent upon the number of points placed into the EyesightPoints attribute. Animals may also hide within your radius by using camouflage. This means that more points placed into the EyesightPoints attribute will yield a better vision of hidden creatures.

Because of camouflage and the random aspect of hiding vs. being seen by another creature, multiple calls to Scan might returns different results. However, each call to Scan also takes additional time from your creature's total timeslice.

It is recommended that you hold onto the OrganismState objects, determine your target creature, and then use the LookFor method to update the state rather than calling the Scan method again. The LookFor method also takes into account camouflage and may not work the first time, but is much less expensive timewise than Scan.

member.returns: System.Collections.ArrayList of OrganismState objects your creature can see.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.RefreshState(System.String)

summary.para: Tries to return an updated OrganismState given a creature's ID. This function may return null if the creature can't be found or was hidden by camouflage. You may call this method multiple times just like the LookFor method and get different results.

member.param: GUID which represents a specific organism in the system.
member.returns: OrganismState representing the creature being looked for or null if not found.
member.exception: Thrown if the organismID parameter is null.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.LookFor(Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState)

summary.para: Tries to return an updated OrganismState given a creature's state OrganismState. This function may return null if the creature can't be found or was hidden by camouflage. You may call this method multiple times and get different results.

member.param: The stale OrganismState object you want to refresh.
member.returns: OrganismState representing the creature being looked for or null if not found.
member.exception: Thrown if the organismState parameter is null.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.IsMySpecies(Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState)

summary.para: Allows a creature to determine if the OrganismState of another creature represents the same species. This can be used to determine whether you should attack/defend against another creature.

Creatures of the same species often don't fight one another, defend against one another, and kill one another. They often help their own species in fights against other species. Carnivores of the same species may sacrifice themselves as food once they become too old to members of their species.

member.param: The OrganismState for the creature to be used in species comparison.
member.returns: True if the organism owning the state object is of the same species, false otherwise.
member.exception: Thrown if the targetState parameter is null.

summary.para: Clears any pending movement operations your creature might be performing.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.BeginMoving(Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.MovementVector)

summary.para: Method used to command a creature to begin moving towards a specific location at a specific speed. The actual movement operation may take several turns, but is always initiated using this method. Your movement location should be within the world boundary and your movement speed should be less than or equal to your creature's Species.MaximumSpeed.

Once called the creature will begin moving towards the specified point. This movement will continue until you issue a different BeginMoving command to your creature, it reaches its destination, or becomes blocked by something. Any calls to BeginMoving will clear out any previous calls, so care should be taken when issuing multi-part path movements.

Once the movement is completed the MoveCompleted event will be fired and your event handler for this function will be called if you've provided one. The event handler will provide full information about the results of an attempted movement operation.

member.param: The MovementVector that determines the point you are moving to and how fast to move there.
member.exception: Thrown if the vector parameter is null.
Thrown if the destination is outside of the world boundaries.
Thrown if the speed defined in the vector is greater than Species.MaximumSpeed.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.BeginDefending(Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.AnimalState)

summary.para: Method used to command a creature to begin defending against a specific target creature. You can only defend against one creature at a time, so only the final call to BeginDefending will actually be used in the upcoming turn.

Once your creature has finished defending, the DefendCompleted event will be fired and your event handler will be called if you provided one. You can use this event to determine the results of your defense.

member.param: The AnimalState that represents the animal you want to defend against.
member.exception: Thrown if the targetAnimal parameter is null.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.BeginAttacking(Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.AnimalState)

summary.para: Method used to command your creature to start attacking another creature. You can only attack one creature per round, and a single call to BeginAttacking will only attack a target creature in the upcoming tick. Calling BeginAttacking multiple times in the same turn will only result in your creature attacking the target specified in the last call to BeginAttacking.

Attacking is asynchronous so you'll need to handle the AttackCompleted event in order to get the status of your attack. A single attack might not kill a target enemy so you should detect if the enemy is still alive and call BeginAttacking once per round until the target creature is either dead or has escaped.

member.param: The AnimalState object that represents the creature you want your creature to attack.
member.exception: Thrown if the targetAnimal parameter is null.
Thrown if the creature is not hungry enough to attack.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.WithinEatingRange(Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState)

summary.para: Used to determine if your creature is within range to eat another target creature.

This method does not attempt to validate the position of the organismState with respect to the current world state. If you pass a stale object in then you may get stale results. Make sure you use the LookFor method to get the most up-to-date results.

member.param: OrganismState of the creature you're thinking of eating.
member.returns: True if the creature is within range to eat, False otherwise.
member.exception: Thrown if the targetOrganism parameter is null.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.WithinAttackingRange(Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.AnimalState)

summary.para: Used to determine if your creature is within range to attack another target creature.

This method does not attempt to validate the position of the organismState with respect to the current world state. If you pass a stale object in then you may get stale results. Make sure you use the LookFor method to get the most up-to-date results.

member.param: OrganismState of the creature you're thinking of attacking.
member.returns: True if the creature is within range to attack, False otherwise.
member.exception: Thrown if the targetOrganims parameter is null

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.BeginEating(Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState)

summary.para: Method used to command your creature to start eating another creature. You can only eat one target creature per round, and a single call to BeginEating will only attack a target creature in the upcoming tick. Calling BeginEating multiple times in the same turn will only result in your creature eating the target specified in the last call to BeginEating.

Eating is asynchronous so you'll need to handle the EatCompleted event in order to get the status of the bite. A single bite might not produce enough energy for your creature so you'll have to make multiple bites against the same target until it is completed eaten.

member.param: OrganismState of the creature you wish to eat.
member.exception: Thrown if the targetOrganism parameter is null.
Thrown if your creature is not hungry enough to eat.
Thrown if the creature had disappeared from your creature's view.
Thrown if your creature is not within eating distance.
Thrown if a Carnivore tries to eat a plant or a Herbivore tries to eat an Animal
Thrown if a Carnivore tries to eat a creature that isn't dead yet.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.CanAttack(Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.AnimalState)

summary.para: Used to determine if your creature can attack another creature. This will return true all the time for a Carnivore since they can always attack.

For Herbivores this will return true if they are hungry enough to be aggressive. Herbivores may also attack a creature in the upcoming round if that creature attacked them in the previous round. The best place to attack a creature that is attacking you is to handle the Attacked event.

member.param: AnimalState for the creature you would like to attack.
member.returns: True if your creature can attack the target creature, False otherwise.
member.exception: Thrown if the targetAnimal parameter is null.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.IsMoving

summary.para: Used to determine if your creature has been commanded to move. You can also check the CurrentMoveToAction property to get the actual movement vector for your creature. Because moving is asynchronous your creature might not have started moving yet.

member.returns: True if your creature is or will be moving, False otherwise.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.CurrentDefendAction

summary.para: After your creature has begun defending you can get the DefendAction object that represents you're creatures current defend action. You can use this to examine the target creature you're defending against and determine if there might be a more appropriate enemy.

member.returns: A DefendAction object representing the current defend action and the values passed into BeginDefending.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.IsDefending

summary.para: Used to determine if your creature has been commanded to defend. You can also check the CurrentDefendAction property to get the actual target creature you're defending against. Because defending is asynchronous your creature won't defend until the upcoming tick.

member.returns: True if your creature will defend the next tick, False otherwise.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.CurrentAttackAction

summary.para: After your creature has begun attacking you can get the AttackAction object that represents your creature's current attack action. You can use this to examine the target creature you're attacking and determine if there might be a more appropriate enemy.

member.returns: AttackAction object representing the current attack action and the values passed into BeginAttacking.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.IsAttacking

summary.para: Used to determine if your creature has been commanded to attack. You can also check the CurrentAttackAction property to get the actual target creature you're attacking. Because attacking is asynchronous your creature won't attack until the upcoming tick.

member.returns: True if your creature will attack the next tick, False otherwise.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.CurrentEatAction

summary.para: After your creature has begun eating you can get the EatAction object that represents you're creatures current eat action. You can use this to examine the target creature your eating and determine if their might be a better target to eat.

member.returns: EatAction object representing the current eat action and the values passed into BeginEating.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.IsEating

summary.para: Used to determine if your creature has been commanded to eat. You can also check the CurrentEatAction property to get the actual target creature you're eating. Because eating is asynchronous your creature won't actually eat until the upcoming tick.

member.returns: True if your creature will eat the next tick, False otherwise.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.CanEat

summary.para: Used to determine if your creature is capable of eating depending on the creature's current energy state. You can also trap the AlreadyFullException from BeginEating.

member.returns: True if your creature is hungry enough to eat, False otherwise.

summary.para: The MoveCompleted event is fired whenever your creature has completed a movement operation. This can either mean the creature reached the destination or that the creature was blocked and can't move anymore.

The AttackCompleted event is fired whenever your creature has completed an attack operation. Your creature should hook this event to learn the results of the battle such as how much damage was inflicted and whether the target creature was killed.

member.summary: Fired when an EatAction is completed.

member.summary: Fired after all other events have been fired.

member.name: E:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.Load
member.summary: Fired before all other events have been fired.

member.name: E:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.Teleported

member.name: E:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.ReproduceCompleted

member.name: E:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Animal.DefendCompleted

summary.para: Provides access to a creature's Antenna. Each creature has two Antenna that can be placed in 10 different positions each. This enables a multitude of states that can be used to communicate with other creatures of the same species or even creatures of different species.

By default both Antenna are positioned to the AntennaPosition.Left. In addition to setting the state of each individual Antenna. The author can also use the AntennaValue property to set a number from 0 to 99. This is provided for ease of use since most author developers will use this structure for passing data (cell data maybe?) rather than simple flags or states.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.AntennaState.#ctor(Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.AntennaPosition,Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.AntennaPosition)

summary.para: Constructs a new AntennaState given the initial values for the LeftAntenna and RightAntenna. If the values are not within the ranged allowed by the AntennaState they will be defaulted to AntennaPosition.Left;

member.param: AntennaPosition that will be assigned to LeftAntenna.
AntennaPosition that will be assigned to RightAntenna.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.AntennaState.#ctor(Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.AntennaState)

summary.para: Constructs a new AntennaState given the initial values from a pre-existing AntennaState. This effectively makes a copy without making the new state immutable. This can be used to copy states from another creature and then modified slightly.

member.param: AntennaState used to initialize the LeftAntenna and RightAntenna properties.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.AntennaState.LeftAntenna

summary.para: Used to get the position of the LeftAntenna. You can also set the position of the LeftAntenna if the AntennaState is not set to immutable. By default the AntennaState located on the Animal class is never marked immutable, and the AntennaState located on the AnimalState class is always immutable.
You may also use the AntennaValue property if you are just trying to pass simple numbers or are organizing a state machine that has more than 10 specific states.

member.returns: AntennaPosition representing the location of the LeftAntenna

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.AntennaState.RightAntenna

summary.para: Used to get the position of the RightAntenna. You can also set the position of the RightAntenna if the AntennaState is not set to immutable. By default the AntennaState located on the Animal class is never marked immutable, and the AntennaState located on the AnimalState class is always immutable.
You may also use the AntennaValue property if you are just trying to pass simple numbers or are organizing a state machine that has more than 10 specific states.

member.returns: AntennaPosition representing the location of the LeftAntenna

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.AntennaState.AntennaValue

summary.para: Used to get a numeric value between 0 and 99 that represents the AntennaPosition of both the LeftAntenna and RightAntenna. You can also set the position of both Antenna by specifying a new value between 0 and 99 if the AntennaState is not set to immutable. By default the AntennaState located on the Animal class is never marked immutable, and the AntennaState located on the AnimalState class is always immutable.
You may also set each of the Antenna separately rather than using this special value that represents both Antenna numerically.

member.returns: AntennaPosition representing the location of the LeftAntenna

summary.para: This attribute is required to be present on all creatures so that a creature's author can be identified for prize competitions. It accepts both an Author Name, and an Email. The Author Name will be used on charting pages and top x graphs, while the Email will ONLY be made available to the Terrarium team to contact users for prizes.

item.term: Attacks against smaller animals are more effective (damage inflicted is per unit of radius) which means there are more animals you can eat
Defends against smaller animals are more effective (damage deterred is per unit of radius)
Burn more energy per turn to stay alive, and to move (which means you need to eat more)
Takes longer to reach maturity and thus to give birth

member.summary: Points applied to the MaximumEnergyPoints Attribute determine how much energy your animal can store -- it determines how often your organism has to eat.

remarks.para: If you apply lots of points to this attribute, your animal will be like a snake: it can fill up and not have to eat for a long time. Less points here means you'll be more like a hummingbird: you'll need to eat small amounts constantly.

summary.para: Describes the event handler required in order to hook into a creature's AttackCompleted event. The sender will always be your creature, and AttackCompletedEventArgs will be filled with information to help your creature process it's turn.

This event will be fired after every attack your creature initiates. The returned AttackCompletedEventArgs will contain information about damage dealt, whether the creature is dead, or whether it got away.
Special object used to hold arguments passed to the AttackedEventHandler delegate. Contains the state of the creature attacking your creature. This is useful in setting up a good defense

member.returns: System.String representing the contents of this class.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Events.AttackedEventArgs.Attacker

summary.para: Provides the state of the creature attacking your creature. You can use this state to attack the creature back, defend, or run away.

member.returns: AnimalState representing the state of the creature attacking you.

summary.para: Describes the event handler required in order to hook into a creature's Attacked event. The sender will always be your creature, and AttackedEventArgs will be filled with information to help your creature process it's turn.
This event may be fired more than once per turn and will be fired once for each creature that initiates an attack against your creature assuming your creature lives through the battle.

member.returns: a System.Byte[] of special data usable by a child creature.

summary.para: Describes the event handler required in order to hook into a creature's Born event. The sender will always be your creature, and BornEventArgs will be filled with information to help your creature process it's turn.

This event may be fired once for your creature when it is first born, in which case the BornEventArgs might have some Dna from the parent, or none if the creatures were made by the Terrarium game engine during introduction.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.Events.EatCompletedEventArgs.Successful

summary.para: Provides information about whether or not an eat action was successful. Often times if multiple creatures are eating the state target, the target will run out of food value before all creatures get to eat. In this case the eat won't be successful and the creature won't gain any energy.

member.returns: True if your creature gained energy from eating, False otherwise.

member.name: T:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.Creature.PendingActions
member.summary:
This is a class so that we can get the whole set of actions in one chunk because they were remoted at one point.
These pending actions can only be set, never read by the code in the species. From the developer's perspective, they just called a method the TickActions class gathers these up and sets them to null This is to ensure that we don't need locks.

summary.para: EngineSettings contains all of the various constants that affect the game world, creature attributes, and computed values for the Terrarium. Creatures may use these values in order to decisions or calculate new values of their own. These should be thought of as the laws of physics and biology for the Terrarium.
The amount of energy required per tick in order to incubate an offspring. This is multiplied by the creature's Radius so larger creatures require more energy to incubate than smaller creatures.
The amount of time in game ticks that a creature can stay alive. This number is multiplied by the creature's MatureSize so smaller creatures will not live as long as larger creatures.
The maximum number of healing points a creature can heal per tick. This is multiplied by the Radius of the creature and so larger creatures can heal many more points than smaller creatures.

The amount of time in game ticks that a creature must wait before being able to reproduce. This number is multiplied by the creature's Radius and so larger creatures take longer between reproductions than smaller creatures.
The amount of energy required to heal a creature by a single health unit.

The amount of energy burned by a creature in order to grow a single unit of radius. For smaller creatures this amount of energy will be quite taxing, but as the creature grows larger the amount of energy taken doesn't affect the creature as much.

The amount of energy burned by a creature each tick just for being alive in the game. This constant is multiplied by the creature's radius so smaller creatures been less energy per tick than larger creatures.

Represents the base amount of damage that can be absorbed by a creature that places 0 points into the DefendDamagePointsAttribute. The amount of damage absorption taken from this constant is multiplied by the current radius of the creature. This means both MatureSize and the DefendDamagePointsAttribute can increase the amount of damage your creature can take.

Represents the base food chunks per bite granted to a creature that puts 0 points into the EatingSpeedPointsAttribute. The number of food chunks taken from this constant is multiplied by the current radius of the creature. This means both MatureSize and the EatingSpeedPointsAttribute can increase the number of food chunks taken per bite.
Represents the base distance a creature can see if they place 0 points into the EyesightPointsAttribute.
This distance is in Terrarium Cells, so you have to multiply by 8 to get the actual distance in Terrarium Units (pixels).

Represents the base amount of damage that can be dealt by a creature that places 0 points into the AttackDamagePointsAttribute. The amount of damage taken from this constant is multiplied by the current radius of the creature. This means both MatureSize and the AttackDamagePointsAttribute can increase the amount of damage your creature can dish out.
The amount of energy burned by a plant each tick just for being alive in the game. This constant is multiplied by the plant's radius so smaller plants been less energy per tick than larger plants.

Attack and Defense modifier applied to Carnivores. This gives Carnivores an advantage in both attacking and defending against Herbivores since they have to attack and expend extra energy to obtain food.
This multiplier is used to modify the life span for Carnivores. Since Carnivores have double the lifespan of Herbivores they get twice as many opportunities for reproduction
The amount of damage required to before a creature is killed. This is multiplied by the Radius of the creature and so larger creatures can take many more hits than smaller creatures.
The amount of energy given to a creature for one food chunk from a corpse.
The amount of energy given to a creature for one food chunk from a plant.
The amount of food chunks a creature amounts to once they become a corpse. Larger creatures will have a larger amount of food chunks available to predators than smaller creatures.
Represents the lowest attainable odds of appearing invisible in the Terrarium. In order to achieve this minimum available camouflage you must apply 0 points to the CamouflagePointsAttribute.

Represents the highest attainable odds of appearing invisible in the Terrarium. In order to achieve this maximum camouflage MaxAvailableCharacteristicPoints must be applied to the CamouflagePointsAttribute.
Represents the maximum number of characteristic points available for creature developers to assign to characteristic stats.
Represents the amount of energy storage per unit radius granted to a creature when 0 points have been placed into the MaximumEnergyPointsAttribute.
Even if 0 points are placed into the MaximumEnergyPointsAttribute a creature can still achieve higher energy storage by increasing MatureSize.
The maximum amount of energy a plant can gain per tick from the natural light of the EcoSystem.

Represents the highest attainable energy storage per unit radius. In order to achieve this maximum available energy you must apply MaxAvailableCharacteristicPoints to the MaximumEnergyPointsAttribute.

Please note that this value multiplied by your current radius is your actual total energy storage. This means that putting points into the MaximumEnergyPointsAttribute or increasing the MatureSize of your creature will both increase the total energy storage.

Represents the maximum amount of damage that can be absorbed by a creature that places MaxAvailableCharacteristicPoints into the DefendDamagePointsAttribute. The amount of damage absorption taken from this constant is multiplied by the current radius of the creature. This means both MatureSize and the DefendDamagePointsAttribute can increase the amount of damage your creature can take.

Represents the maximum number of food chunks per bite that can be taken by a creature that places MaxAvailableCharacteristicPoints into the EatingSpeedPointsAttribute. The number of food chunks taken from this constant is multiplied by the current radius of the creature. This means both MatureSize and the EatingSpeedPointsAttribute can increase the number of food chunks taken per bite.
Represents the maximum distance a creature can see if they place MaxAvailableCharacteristicPoints into the EyesightPointsAttribute.
This distance is in Terrarium Cells, so you have to multiply by 8 to get the actual distance in Terrarium Units (pixels).

Represents the maximum amount of damage that can be dealt by a creature that places MaxAvailableCharacteristicPoints into the AttackDamagePointsAttribute. The amount of damage taken from this constant is multiplied by the current radius of the creature. This means both MatureSize and the AttackDamagePointsAttribute can increase the amount of damage your creature can dish out.
Represents the largest possible value that can be placed into the MatureSize attribute. No creature may grow to be larger than this constant.
The maximum distance that a plant can spread its seeds when reproducing.
Represents the smallest possible value that can be placed into the MatureSize attribute. No creature may grow to maturity and still be smaller than this constant.
The amount of food chunks a plant amounts to. Larger plants will have a larger amount of food chunks available to herbivores than smaller plants.
The amount of energy required per tick in order to incubate an offspring. This is multiplied by the plant's Radius so larger plants require more energy to incubate than smaller plants.
The amount of time in game ticks that a plant can stay alive. This number is multiplied by the plant's MatureSize so smaller plants will not live as long as larger plants.
The maximum number of healing points a plant can heal per tick. This is multiplied by the Radius of the plant and so larger plants can heal many more points than smaller plants.

The amount of time in game ticks that a plant must wait before being able to reproduce. This number is multiplied by the plant's Radius and so larger plants take longer between reproductions than smaller plants.
The amount of energy required to heal a plant by a single health unit.

The amount of energy burned by a plant in order to grow a single unit of radius. For smaller plants this amount of energy will be quite taxing, but as the plant grows larger the amount of energy taken doesn't affect the plant as much.

The amount of energy burned by a creature in order to move. If you take the speed the creature is moving, the radius, and the distance they are moving along with this constant you can judge how much energy will be expended.

Note that RadiusSpeedDistance is equal to Radius * Speed * Distance. This means that the faster a creature moves the more energy will be consumed for equal distances. A creature should make sure only to move as fast as necessary to conserve energy.
Represents the base achievable speed granted to a creature that places 0 points into the MaximumSpeedAttribute.
Represents the maximum achievable speed granted to a creature that places MaxAvailableCharacteristicPoints into the MaximumSpeedAttribute.
The amount of time in game ticks that is required between a call to BeginReproduction and a new creature actually being born from the parent.

The amount of time in game ticks that a creature's corpse stays in the EcoSystem before it rots away and is removed. Carnivores should make sure to quickly pounce on dead corpses as a food source before they rot.

summary.para: Rotates a vector about the origin by an angle given in Radians radians.

A point (x,y) can be rotated around the origin (0,0) by running it through the following equations to get the new point (x',y'): x' = cos(theta)*x - sin(theta)*y y' = sin(theta)*x + cos(theta)*y where theta is the angle by which to rotate the point.

summary.para: Represents a creature's state during a certain tick in time. This class provides information on the creature's species, how much damage the creature has taken, and methods to compute energy requirements.
For additional information you should look at the OrganismState class which provides information that is shared between the Plant/Animal states.
All properties of an organism that are used by the game are on this object. Each OrganismState is immutable and references can be held as long as the organism needs them.
This object only represents the state of a creature for a given turn and is not dynamically updated. Creatures should use the LookFor method in order to get the latest state of another creature.

member.summary: Add a single tick to the current incubation period. Called by the game engine each tick after the creature starts reproducing. Once the amount of ticks hits the limit for the amount of time required to incubate a child, the creature is born, and incubation is no longer required.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.IncreaseRadiusTo(System.Int32)
member.summary: Used by the game engine to increase the radius of a creature to a new radius amount. Each time a creature grows this method is called to set the new radius. The new radius must be larger than the previous one, so creatures can't shrink. The radius can be increased by more than a single unit, but the current Terrarium only encompasses methods that increase a radius by a single unit.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.SetBitmapDirection
member.summary: Determines the facing of the creature based on the movement vector and update the creature's actual direction as a result.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.Kill(Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.PopulationChangeReason)
member.summary: Called by the game engine in order to kill the current creature. Since this method can only be called when the state is mutable player's can't use the method to arbitrarily kill competing organisms.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.Grow
member.summary: This returns a clone because we need the radius to be editable and the object may not allow this because it is already in the index the object returned will have the same events as the original

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.ResetGrowthWait
member.summary: Used by the game engine to reset the amount of time the creature must wait before growing. The wait time is based on the creature's species class which uses the creature's lifepsan as a base for the growth period. This should be called after a creature has been given the chance to grow, and must wait before growing again.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.HealDamage
member.summary: Required override for other state classes. This method gives the creature a chance to heal some previously inflicted damage.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.IsAdjacentOrOverlapping(Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState)

summary.para: Determines if a creature is immediately next to or overlapping another creature using grid cells comparisons.

member.param: OrganismState of the creature to check for proximity.
member.returns: True if the creature is adjacent or overlapping, False otherwise.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.IsWithinRect(System.Int32,Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState)
member.summary: Used to compute whether or not a given state object is in an adjacent or overlapping grid cell. The extra radius can be used to extend the area used for the function to find a match and so can be used for functions like visibiliy.
member.param: The amount of extra grid cells to add
The organism state of the creature to use in the area test.
member.returns: True if the creature is within range, false otherwise.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.IsImmutable
member.summary: Determines if the current creature state is immutable.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.PreviousDisplayAction
member.summary: Returns the action that the organism was performing between the last state and this one. I.e. what ended on this state.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.RenderInfo
member.summary: This property remains mutable even though the rest of the object is immutable because it is used by the renderer and maintains rendering state across worldstate instances (like whether the organism is selected or not).

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.OrganismEvents
member.summary: When events are completed the completion actions get listed into a collection of completed events. These are then used by the processing functions to fire off events on the creature.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.Species

summary.para: Describes the characteristics of a creature through the use of the ISpecies interface.

member.returns: ISpecies interface representing the characteristics of the creature.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.IsMature

summary.para: Determines if the creature is mature by comparing the current Radius to the Radius it will have when mature.

member.returns: True if the creature is mature, False otherwise.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.DeathReason

summary.para: Describes the reason why the creature died. This is most often OldAge, Starvation, Killed, or Sickness. If the creature is not dead yet then the value will be NotDead.

member.returns: PopulationChangeReason describing the reason for death.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.TickAge

summary.para: Represents the age of a creature in game ticks. Once a creature reaches a TickAge identical to its LifeSpan the creature will die from PopulationChangeReason.OldAge.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the age of the creature in game ticks.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.Generation

summary.para: Generation will be 0 the first time a creature is introduced. Each offspring of a creature will be labeled with its generation plus one. This helps define the longevity of a creature.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the generation number for this creature.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.CurrentReproduceAction
member.summary: Used to obtain or modify the current action representing the creature's reproduction status. If this value is not null then the creature is reproducing.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.ReadyToReproduce

summary.para: Determines if a creature is ready to reproduce based on the elapsed time since its previous reproduction. Use ReproductionWait to determine exactly how long the creature has to go.

member.returns: True if the creature is ready to reproduce. False otherwise.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.ReproductionWait

summary.para: Determines the number of ticks the creature must wait before reproducing again. If your creature just needs to know if it's ready the ReadyToReproduce property can be used instead.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the time in ticks before the creature can reproduce.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.IsIncubating

summary.para: Determines if the creature is in the process of reproduction. Use IncubationTicks to find out exactly how long the creature has left to incubate.

member.returns: True if the creature is in the process of reproducing, False otherwise.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.IncubationTicks

summary.para: Determines the number of ticks the creature must wait before it has finished reproducing. If your creature just needs to know if it's currently reproducing use the IsIncubating property.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the number of ticks left for incubation.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.FoodChunks

summary.para: Determines the amount of food value this creature represents. This can be used to determine if attacking a creature will be worth the effort.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the number of food chunks this creature represents.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.StoredEnergy

summary.para: Determines how much energy a creature has stored. This is used to compute the energy state of the creature.

member.returns: System.Double representing the amount of energy this creature has stored.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.EnergyState

summary.para: Determine the current energy state of a creature by comparing the current amount of stored energy versus the various energy buckets.

member.returns: EnergyState enum representing the creature's current energy state.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.PercentEnergy

summary.para: Determines the decimal percentage of the amount of energy a creature currently has, versus the total amount of energy the creature can store.

member.returns: System.Double between 0 and 1, with 0 being none and 1 being maxed.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.PercentLifespanRemaining

summary.para: Determines the decimal percentage of the amount of life remaining a creature currently has, versus the total amount of LifeSpan.

member.returns: System.Double between 0 and 1, with 1 being newly born, and 0 being dead.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.PercentInjured
member.summary: Must be overriden in derived classes and compute a factor that can be used to represent the injury done to the creature.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.Position

summary.para: Returns the creature's current position as a Point.

member.returns: Terrarium.Sdk.Helpers.Point representing the creature's current location.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.GridX

summary.para: Retrieves the creature's current grid location. This is useful for movement algorithms and is used by the engine for computing organism location in a fast and memory efficient manner.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the Terrarium grid cell for the center of the organism.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.GridY

summary.para: Retrieves the creature's current grid location. This is useful for movement algorithms and is used by the engine for computing organism location in a fast and memory efficient manner.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the Terrarium grid cell for the center of the organism.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.CellRadius

summary.para: Determines the number of game cells a creature uses on the screen. Each grid cell is 8 pixels in width and height.

member.returns: System.Int32 for the grid cells the creature's radius represents.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.Radius

summary.para: Determines the actual radius of the creature. This is used to determine how close to maturity a creature has gotten or in various computations on attack, defense, and movement.

member.returns: System.Int32 of the actual radius of the creature.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.ID

summary.para: A string number in the form of a GUID that uniquely represents this creature in the EcoSystem.

member.returns: System.String uniquely identifying this creature in the EcoSystem.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.CurrentMoveToAction
member.summary: Retrieves information about the creature's current movement vector. If the creature is moving this value will always be non null, and null if the creature isn't currently moving. This is used by the game engine since movement can encompass many turns.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.Speed

summary.para: Determines the speed at which the creature is moving. Useful in calculating overtake speeds for Carnivores and run-away speeds for Herbivores.

member.returns: System.Int32 for the speed the creature is moving.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.ActualDirection

summary.para: Determines the direction the creature is moving in degrees. This along with Speed can be used to calculate where a creature will be in the future.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the direction the creature is moving in degrees.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.IsStopped

summary.para: Determines if the creature is moving or is completely stopped.

member.returns: True if the creature is moving, False otherwise.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.IsAlive

summary.para: Determines if the creature is alive or dead. This is used by Carnivores so they can find food in the form of corpses.

member.returns: True if the creature is alive, False otherwise.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState.GrowthWait

summary.para: Determines the amount of time in game ticks a creature must wait before they are able to grow. If a creature is not yet mature, and the GrowthWait is 0, then it is possible the creature does not have enough energy or enough space in order to grow. This should be remedied quickly.

member.returns: System.Int32 for the amount of time in game ticks a creature has before they can grow.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.AnimalState.EnergyRequiredToMove(System.Double,System.Int32)

summary.para: Provides a method for creatures to determine how much energy a specific movement action will cost. The slower a creature moves the less energy they expend moving over a specific distance. With this in mind the developer can determine the optimum speed at which to move to a given location versus time and energy consumption.

member.param: The amount of distance your creature is going to move.
The speed your creature is going to move at.
member.returns: System.Double representing the amount of energy required to make the movement action.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.AnimalState.Antennas

summary.para: Provides access to a read-only version of a creature's Antenna. Each Antenna has a specific set of positions that it may be in. Setting states with this information is possible as is passing numeric data.
This property is used to examine the Antenna state of other creatures. If you need to set the states of your own Antenna you should use the Antennas property on the Animal base class.

member.returns: AntennaState for the organism to initiate communication.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.AnimalState.AnimalSpecies

summary.para: Provides information about the Species of the creature through the IAnimalSpecies interface. This should be used to determine the stats of a creature for threat/food calculations.

member.returns: IAnimalSpecies representing the Species of the creature this state represents.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.AnimalState.RotTicks

summary.para: Provides the number of ticks a particular corpse has been rotting for. This is useful to determine whether a corpse will be around long enough to be used for food.
Under normal circumstances a corpse will remain for 100 ticks. However, this number may be shortened if the machine is under load and many creatures are dying from sickness.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the number of ticks the creature has been dead.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.AnimalState.PercentInjured

summary.para: Provides the percentage of damage taken versus total allowed damage before the creature is killed. This is useful in calculating which creature makes the best target due to weakness.

member.returns: System.Double decimal percentage of total injury. 0 Representing maximum health and 1 representing death.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.AnimalState.Damage

summary.para: Provides the absolute amount of damage an organism has sustained. Normally PercentInjured is more useful for determining how badly hurt your creature is, but this absolute number can be used for different types of calculations.

Some useful applications include examining the damage taken each tick, determining which creature has the MOST damage, not the highest percentage of damage. Determining if your creature can sustain a hit from another creature without dying. Determining a creature's statistical chance of winning a fight, along with updating this chance each round. Each of these can be done using the Damage property, but not the PercentInjured property.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the absolute amount of damage taken.

summary.para: For additional information you should look at the OrganismState class which provides information that is shared between the Plant/Animal states.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.PlantState.heightToRadiusRatio
member.summary: Determines how high a plant is compared to its base. This can be used to make squatty plants or tall plants. This is currently not used. Height could be derived from this ratio, and it should probably be made into a characteristic.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.PlantState.optimalLightPercentage
member.summary: This is incomplete, this should be a characteristic that enables creatures to determine how much light they need to obtain maximum energy per tick. This can be used to create trees that require lots of light or moss that requires very little.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.PlantState.#ctor(System.String,Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.ISpecies,System.Int32,Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.EnergyState,System.Int32)

member.summary: Copies the value of the current state into a new state object. Used by the CloneMutable method to make mutable copies of state objects.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.PlantState.GiveEnergy(System.Int32)
member.summary: The amount of energy a plant gets decreases linearly as you get away from the optimal
member.param: The amount of light available to give to this plant.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.PlantState.IncreaseRadiusTo(System.Int32)

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.PlantState.Grow

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.PlantState.Height

summary.para: Returns the height of the plant.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.PlantState.CurrentMaxFoodChunks

member.returns: System.Double representing the percentage of defoliation on a plant.

summary.para: Used by the AnimalSkin attribute. Similar to a "font family" in windows, this enum specifies which family of skins to use when displaying an creature whose custom skin can't be loaded.
Use the Ant skin if the custom skin can't be loaded.
Use the Beetle skin if the custom skin can't be loaded.
Use the Spider skin if the custom skin can't be loaded.
Use the Inchworm skin if the custom skin can't be loaded.
Use the Scorpion skin if the custom skin can't be loaded.
Provides the various positions that the LeftAntenna and RightAntenna may be in. Values outside of the allowable range are thrown away and will always default to AntennaPosition.Left.
The Antenna will be facing Left, this demonstrates a numeric value of 0 when using the AntennaValue property of AntennaState.
The Antenna will be facing Right, this demonstrates a numeric value of 1 when using the AntennaValue property of AntennaState.
The Antenna will be facing Up, this demonstrates a numeric value of 2 when using the AntennaValue property of AntennaState.
The Antenna will be facing Down, this demonstrates a numeric value of 3 when using the AntennaValue property of AntennaState.
The Antenna will be facing to the Upper Left, this demonstrates a numeric value of 4 when using the AntennaValue property of AntennaState.
The Antenna will be facing to the Upper Right, this demonstrates a numeric value of 5 when using the AntennaValue property of AntennaState.
The Antenna will be facing to the Bottom Left, this demonstrates a numeric value of 6 when using the AntennaValue property of AntennaState.
The Antenna will be facing to the Bottom Right, this demonstrates a numeric value of 7 when using the AntennaValue property of AntennaState.
The Antenna will be facing Forward, this demonstrates a numeric value of 8 when using the AntennaValue property of AntennaState.
The Antenna will be facing Backward, this demonstrates a numeric value of 9 when using the AntennaValue property of AntennaState.

member.name: T:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.DisplayAction
member.summary: Used to determine what the most prominent completed action for the previous tick was. This is used by the rendering engine to decide which animation should be used. Note that the values of the enumeration were initially set to enable quick render processing, but the values are now much less important.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.DisplayAction.Attacked
member.summary: The creature attacked. This happens quite a bit and is a very prominent display action.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.DisplayAction.Defended
member.summary: The creature defended. This also hapens quite a bit and is a very prominent display action.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.DisplayAction.Dead
member.summary: The creature was dead in the previous tick and is still dead.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.DisplayAction.Died
member.summary: The creature died in the previous tick and the dying animation should be performed if there is one.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.DisplayAction.Ate
member.summary: The creature was eating in the previous tick.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.DisplayAction.Moved
member.summary: The creature was moving in the previous tick.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.DisplayAction.NoAction
member.summary: The creature was not performing any actions.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.DisplayAction.Teleported
member.summary: The creature was teleporting in the previous tick. This could be used for a great teleportation animation if one existed.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.DisplayAction.Reproduced
member.summary: The creature was reproducing in the previous tick. The animation for reproduction should be shown if there is one.

summary.para: Contains the different energy levels a creature goes through from Full to Dead. Normal represents the desired energy state for most creatures.
The creature has no energy at this point and can't sustain existence. A creature that reaches this state will die due to Starvation.
The creature has little energy and will soon die from Starvation. When a creature reaches this point it should quickly find some food.

The creature is starting to get low on energy. Most creatures should look for food at this point if they aren't already. Any Herbivore that is at Hungry or below is capable of unprovoked attacks on other creatures.

This is the desired energy zone for most creatures. This is the point where creatures can heal themselves, grow, and reproduce. Creatures have plenty of energy at this point, but can still eat and obtain higher energy levels.
The creature has more than enough energy and can no longer eat. This state can't be maintained for very long and the creature will soon slip back into the normal range again.

member.name: T:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.KnownColor
member.summary: Copy of KnownColor from System.Drawing (so we don't have to include it in the SDK)

summary.para: Used by the PlantSkin attribute. Similar to a font family, this enum specifies which family of skins to use when displaying an creature whose custom skin can't be loaded.
Use the Plant skin (grass number 1) if the custom skin can't be loaded.
Use the PlantOne skin (grass number 1) if the custom skin can't be loaded.
Use the PlantTwo skin (grass number 2) if the custom skin can't be loaded.
Use the PlantThree skin (grass number 3) if the custom skin can't be loaded.
Describes the reason for the death of a creature.
The creature is not dead yet. This will be returned by all creatures that are alive in the Terrarium and is a place holder to represent an undead state.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.PopulationChangeReason.Initial
member.summary: Represents initial population changes instituted whenever the game state is deserialized. These creatures were not added to the game, but were pre-existing. When creating new reporting data this has to be remembered.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.PopulationChangeReason.Born
member.summary: The creature was added to the population through birth.

summary.para: The creature died from old age. This happens once a creature has lived out its entire lifespan.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.PopulationChangeReason.TeleportedTo
member.summary: The creature was removed from the engine because it was teleported to another peer.

summary.para: The creature died do to starvation. If a creature runs completely out of energy then they are considered starved.
The creature is not dead yet. This will be returned by all creatures that are alive in the Terrarium and is a place holder to represent an undead state.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.PopulationChangeReason.TeleportedFrom
member.summary: The creature was added to the engine because it was successfully received from another peer.

summary.para: The creature was killed by the attack of another creature.
The creature threw an exception and was terminated.
The creature performed an action that violated terrarium security.
The creature used too much of a timeslice and was timed out.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.PopulationChangeReason.OrganismBlacklisted
member.summary: The creature was removed from the game engine because it was blacklisted by the hosting code due to a malicious timeout.

summary.para: Defines the various reasons a creature can be stopped. This is currently either DestinationReached or Blocked.
Your creature has arrived at the destination used in the call to BeginMoving. During the traversal of the game area no other creatures or blocking items were encountered.
Your creature was blocked from reaching its destination by another creature. This could either be a plant/inanimate object, or another moving creature.

member.name: T:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.SpeciesServiceStatus
member.summary: This enumeration contains return codes identifying the results of an creature insertion into the Terrarium.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.SpeciesServiceStatus.Success
member.summary: Success identifies an inserted creature.

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.SpeciesServiceStatus.AlreadyExists

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.SpeciesServiceStatus.ServerDown

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.SpeciesServiceStatus.VersionIncompatible

member.name: F:Terrarium.Sdk.Enumerations.SpeciesServiceStatus.PoliCheckAuthorNameFailure

summary.para: Species information properties that are applicable only to animals and that should be made available to developers. Use this to find out general information about a particular animal species' capabilities.

This interface holds all species related information that is common to both plants and animals. Creature developers can access all of this information by using the Species property of an OrganismState object.
All species information is immutable. A creature's species represents its basic capabilities such as the mature size, time between growth spurts, and the life span.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.ISpecies.IsSameSpecies(Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.ISpecies)

summary.para: Used to determine if a creature with the given Species information is the same as another creature given their Species information. This is useful for assessing and remembering the strengths/weaknesses of other creatures.

member.param: ISpecies interface for the creature to be compared with this creature.
member.returns: True if the creature's species information is the same, False otherwise.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.ISpecies.MatureRadius

summary.para: The maximum radius that a creature can achieve once they are fully matured. Once a creature has fully matured they may perform additional actions such as reproduction, while others actions cease such as growth.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the radius of the creature when fully mature.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.ISpecies.ReproductionWait

summary.para: The amount of time in ticks a creature must wait between reproductions. Creatures can normally reproduce more than once in a lifetime, so the time limit between reproduction and the life span of the creature are used to define the maximum number of reproductions.

Each tick ReproductionWait will drop by one. Once the ReproductionWait reaches 0 one of the requirements the CanReproduce property will be met. Once a creature is capable of reproducing a call to BeginReproduction must be made to start incubation.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the number of ticks between reproductions.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.ISpecies.LifeSpan

summary.para: The amount of time in ticks a creature is capable of living. Once the creature reaches the full lifespan of the species it is killed with the reason PopulationChangeReason.OldAge.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the number of ticks a creature can live.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.ISpecies.GrowthWait

summary.para: The amount of time in ticks a creature must wait before growing another unit of radius in size. The initial GrowthWait is defined in such a way that a creature will reach full size or MatureRadius after one half of the LifeSpan.

Each tick GrowthWait will drop by one. Once the GrowthWait reaches 0 the creature will grow if it meets all growth requirements. Growth will happen automatically as long as the requirements for growth have been met.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the number of ticks before a creature can grow.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.ISpecies.MaximumEnergyPerUnitRadius

summary.para: The maximum amount of energy a creature can store for every unit of Radius it has grown. This allows larger creatures to store more energy than smaller creatures.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the maximum amount of energy a creature can store per unit radius.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.ISpecies.Skin

summary.para: Returns the Skin the creature will use when being displayed in the Terrarium.

member.returns: System.String identifying the creature's skin.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalSpecies.SkinFamily

summary.para: Returns the SkinFamily the creature will use when being displayed in the Terrarium.

member.returns: System.String identifying the creature's skin family.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalSpecies.IsCarnivore

summary.para: Determines if a creature is a Carnivore.

member.returns: True if the creature is a Carnivore, False otherwise.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalSpecies.EatingSpeedPerUnitRadius

summary.para: The number of food chunks a creature can eat in one tick per unit Radius. This means larger creatures can eat more than smaller creatures in one tick.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the food chunks that can be eaten per tick per unit radius.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalSpecies.MaximumAttackDamagePerUnitRadius

summary.para: The maximum amount of damage that can be inflicted by a creature in a single tick per unit radius. This means larger creatures can attack harder than smaller creatures per tick.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the maximum damage that can be inflicted per unit radius

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalSpecies.MaximumDefendDamagePerUnitRadius

summary.para: The maximum amount of damage that can be absorbed by a creature in a single tick per unit radius. This means larger creatures can defend better than smaller creatures per tick.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the maximum damage that can be absorbed per unit radius

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalSpecies.MaximumSpeed

summary.para: The maximum speed the creature is capable of moving.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the maximum speed the creature is capable of moving.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalSpecies.InvisibleOdds

summary.para: The odds that a creature is invisible to another creature that uses the Scan method.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the odds a creature will appear invisible.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalSpecies.EyesightRadius

summary.para: The distance that a creature can see. This is used to determine the amount of area to be evaluated in a call to the Scan method.

member.returns: System.Int32 representing the distance a creature can see.

member.name: T:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalWorldBoundary
member.summary: This class represents an Animal's view of the world. An interface is used because the creature needs something to link against, while the actual object exists within the Terrarium Client executable.

member.name: T:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IOrganismWorldBoundary
member.summary: Represents the view available to an organism.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IOrganismWorldBoundary.CurrentOrganismState
member.summary: Gets the most up to date state object for the current creature.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IOrganismWorldBoundary.ID
member.summary: Retrieves the organism ID representing your creature within the world.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IOrganismWorldBoundary.WorldWidth
member.summary: Returns the width of the world in game units (pixels);

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IOrganismWorldBoundary.WorldHeight
member.summary: Returns the height of the world in game units (pixels).

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalWorldBoundary.Scan
member.summary: Provides a method for the creature to scan the surrounding area and discover both hidden and visible creatures within your site range.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalWorldBoundary.LookFor(Terrarium.Sdk.Classes.State.OrganismState)
member.summary: Used to look for a creature given an organism state. The organism state can be stale, and the LookFor function will attempt to return an updated state for the latest tick.

member.name: M:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalWorldBoundary.RefreshState(System.String)
member.summary: Used to look for a creature given an organism ID. If the creature is visible the state will be returned. If not null should be returned.

member.name: P:Terrarium.Sdk.Interfaces.IAnimalWorldBoundary.CurrentAnimalState
member.summary: Retrieves the current state of a creature within the world. This state will be immutable and can't be changed, and actually represents an animal state for the previous tick and not the currently executed tick.

summary.para: Species information properties that are applicable only to plants and that should be made available to developers. Use this to find out general information about a particular plant species' capabilities.
